intro: Argemone subintegrifolia, commonly known as the Mexican poppy or narrow-leaf argemone, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It is characterized by its striking yellow-orange flowers and palmate leaves with a distinctive, finely toothed margin. The plant typically grows in dry, disturbed soils and is often found in open habitats such as fields and roadsides. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is known for its latex-containing stems and leaves. The seeds of Argemone subintegrifolia are sometimes used in traditional medicine, though the plant contains toxic compounds that require caution in handling.
